<@U0A5S2PS7|disposedtrolley> has joined the channel

Hey all. I'm trying to update my app which supports 4.0.3+ to a more material design look. Moving to AppCompatActivity seems the easiest route in terms of getting the new Toolbar and material design animations . However, my current ActionBar uses a drop down list and makes use of the ActionBar.OnNavigationListener. This does not appear to be supported with AppCompatActivity - though I'm not 100% sure. Does anyone know if it is still possible to use a drop down list and AppCompatActivity?
I think you can put a normal Spinner into the ToolBar and use its callbacks. Then you just need to handle the fragment changes
Ohhh, OK - cheers <@U04TK850N> I'll take a look at that

Question: Using EventBus right now to inform my Fragments about Events in a Service. Now if I want to query the Service for info from the Fragments, what would you recommend to do? I assume sending Events and waiting for others to return is a lot of overheard, no?
just doesn’t seem correct since you’re communicating 1-1, I don’t think you’re planning on consuming the events anywhere else
nah, some event will have multiple subscribers
i mean, that particular data request event, only your service is going to respond to that right?
oh, yeah
sorry i don’t know other than that, haven’t worked with services outside big nerd ranch :x
I saw a suggestion to bind the service to the application context and work from there, but that seems off to me
idk, when I think about it I actually do something similar with my retrofit implementation. but it passes the events between an auth proxy and the real service
i’d say just use the bus lol
<@U0546MZGX>: Do you have a hint for me? Do you use EventBus bi-directional?
<@U0546QERR>: I should do that...
I'll do it when i'm finished with this commit
i need to do it for drawable/
i imagine it’s possible in the same fashion
<@U04TK850N>: nope, I don’t use EventBus that way… just to notify whoever is interested on something that just happened, not to ask
hm okay
it depends on what you wanna do
the service could notify more often?
or do you need to have the most recent value / data from it?
hm, I could post a sticky when the service boots up
Use case is: The service manages the wallet, and a fragment needs to display transactions. So obviously, when the Fragment loads, it would need to get the transactions to fill its list
so the sticky event might work. the service would post an event with the most recent event, and when fragments gets resumed / created, it can get that event with the data.
I'm not sure how much data this will be though. also, the service might take a second to be fully started, so I'd need to wait anyway
you could have it run in the background, but not sure if it’s worth it / applicable to your use case
the service will run as foreground service
the only way to ask the service would be binding the activity / fragment to it
(as far as I know)
so sad :disappointed:
<@U0A6DJQDV|francois> has joined the channel
<@U0546MZGX>: nooo please don’t do that
that’s what centralized storage is for, don’t push data with eventbus push notifications
tell things something has happened, don’t presume to know what information they will need
if you do it the way you are talking about I promise you will end up hurting at some point.. been there, stabbed myself on it
<@U0A4WAMNF|shervin> has joined the channel
this is actually why I generally just use broadcasts in my application vs a trendy bus system
if you are just sending a string, its actually more than performant enough =P

so to clarify.. bus style information to send should always be meta data like how you use intents. If you think of them like that you should be sending Actions and related data to that action like a URI or some UUID that references an object in your storage/database. Eventbus is nice because you can define objects that inherently require information. With intents I have to document their requirements and always do validation checking which is cumbersome
yeah, that was my other thought, but it seems like duplicating storage
and then have to keep em in sync
why would you be duplicating storage?
if you sticky an eventbus you are just keeping data in memory which you can do yourself outside of event bus
cause the wallet object already has that info iirc
yeah but it's more transient
then just retain/update
so your service gets the data then hands it to the activity/fragment ?
yeah, cause the object to access it is managed by the service
ok but that object, use that as your data store
you can use callbacks to async fetch from your UI code
use event bus to say when you service has changed the object
granted if you do what im saying the event bus is no longer needed in this case
first droidcon nyc videos are up (not mine)
<https://www.youtube.com/playlist?list=PLnVy79PaFHMUqqvwbjyKJZv1N8rzHOCBi>
woot
jakes is though
oh sweet, I can see the talks I missed :smile:
hmm
well I didn’t mean to send bitmaps on a bus event hehe
but lightweight objects… for sure
and even heavier ones… why not?
because you are potentially moving data that isn’t even needed
well the same happens with listeners. and android is full of them.
this becomes more important when you app grows or you start doing things like making them sticky
sometimes you have to implement a listener interface with 10 methods when you just need one
well those are just bad interfaces =P
many parts of the SDK give you a ton of info when you need everything in there
not saying it’s ok, and I know there are better ways, but not a big deal
also, yes, eventbus is nothing more than a fancy broadcast system
but it’s like okhttp, support libs, glide… any library is nothing more than wrappers around other things and some times providing extra features
that’s literally all it is but android broadcasts where made with IPC in mind
but you could do all that by yourself
yup
it depends on the app and the use case
most of the time, it should be just fine
now, if you work for facebook and you have a dedicated team for each screen…. then, you need to start worrying about this more

but going back.. most of the apps I write are arguably large applications (10k+ lines). This isn’t by itself a ton of code or anything like that as im sure everyone has worked on something larger but I think 10K+ lines is about the area where if you have good structure vs ‘well this doesnt seemingly hurt anything’ you will start hitting gotchas
so im personally very weary of serious mistakes I made that when I started didn’t look like mistakes at all
indeed, you are right
well i mostly do work by myself
and event buses should be used just as a notification system
agreed
and then the receiver should do whatever it needs to do
but sometimes it’s ok to break the rules a bit
NOPE :stuck_out_tongue:
yup :wink:
if your event notifies just one receiver, and that receiver is the only one that is gonna use that data, you should just pass it along
if you store it somewhere to be used by any other component, that’s better for your future self if you really need to do it, but if you don’t… it’s a waste of time. overengineering :smile:

I don’t even wanna think how many hours I’ve spent on backend that would support different databases, different search engines, different everything. I don’t think I’ve ever had to switch from mysql to oracle, for example.
it’s better? yes. necessary? maybe
well.. respectfully disagree :stuck_out_tongue:
well I know :simple_smile:
lol
it depends on what you are working
my personal app that I do just for fun? oh well, I’m not going to spend time on that
i learned a long time ago.. no one at a startup would like me
at work? absolutely
oh I’d love to have someone thinking different
it’s always good to have different points of view

everyone - ‘we can do this thing and its like half the time’
me - ‘but we will have to fix it in a year from now and it will take 3 times longer to fix'
hehe
you always have to compromise
like I physically can’t accept the shortcuts just for the sake of taking them
you have to draw the line somewhere
so i know im a bad startup fit lol
but for example a lot of ppl are just allergic to libraries
because if they get deprecated, you are f****
guilty
im very selective
or if they require something new
yeah and you should be
I made that mistake many years ago, never again
use only what you really need
and if you can, write a wrapper around that library
even if it’s minimal
so it’s easy to switch in the future
last time I made that mistake, I had to rewrite the whole thing. it was just too much work to adapt the code to the new library.
heh i have so many wrapper libraries of what I consider bullshit android API's
wrapper libraries written by you I hope :stuck_out_tongue:
yep
nice
so many of the android API implementations are just like oh god no one wants to write all this boilerplate could you help us out please
this is a good article about this topic <https://sandofsky.com/blog/third-party-libraries.html>
its like ‘hey here write some bugs because whatever'
I avoid wrapper libraries
third-party libraries, that is
all of mine are easily replaceable under the hood. They almost always just take some massive set of callbacks and replace them with a chained builder pattern
NSD is a good example of one i just did
you can really only use the bloody thing one way so why it has so many callbacks I don’t know

but that was a small part of a larger system that basically replicates the nearby api. I cheated though and I am using Android Async which is great because now I ‘can’ do things like encryption if needed
<@U060Q7J2Y>: are they still adding videos or is this all they will add?
no still going
kk, cause bulletproof android was one not there that everyone should watch
about security?
right

the speaker touched on a lot of topics that likely aren’t common knowledge and when you hear them you’ll probably immediately think back to something you did that was unknown to you, terribly insecure
TIL what NIH syndrome is, and that we have a hopeless case of that :confused:
<@U04TK850N>: i can’t imagine why someone would want to reinvent the wheel, but maybe i’ll feel different in 10-20 years when i’m old crusty and think everyone’s code sucks lol
here it's mostly that they are afraid the repos vanish, and also license problems
i hate legal red tape
its a case of mitigating that risk as best you can without having to re-invent the wheel
and that is why we have network calls in asynctasks ._.
you can’t even use libraries under apache v2? retrofit, rxjava?
apache 2 works. we use other things with it. those libs are more an issue cause the patterns they use are unknown to almost all the people I work with
So even I know how to use them, I'd need to teach others
and so maintainability becomes the main issue
rxjava sure, maybe not the best example lol
ive encountered colleagues that havent used retrofit or butterknife
the two on my other project where amazed by Ion... no idea what they'll do if I introduce them to Retrofit :smile:
<@U04U5KS3Z>: I have used neither until I came into this chat :smile:
exactly
i hadnt used rx till i started going through reddit
i watched jdub’s whole talk but i’m still having trouble moving over to retrofit 2 :x
its still beta right?
im in no hurry
i just envisioned it being easier based on the talk
but i dunno, they got rid of RetrofitError and RequestInterceptor on top of which i had a decent bit of code
plus i'm using rxjava observables for the callback which is making things a little confusing with the switch
Request interceptors just become okhttp interceptors now
